question_text: Based on the provided paper content, explain how hydrogen addition affects nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions in dual-fuel diesel engines, focusing specifically on the temperature-related mechanisms mentioned in the citations.
standard_answer: According to the paper, hydrogen addition increases nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions in dual-fuel diesel engines primarily due to elevated in-cylinder temperatures. The paper states that 'hydrogen-fueled diesel engines emit more NOx because of higher in-cylinder temperatures' and notes that 'hydrogen-fueled diesel engines suffer from knocking combustion and higher nitrogen oxide emissions.' These higher temperatures accelerate thermal NO formation through the Zeldovich mechanism, where molecular nitrogen dissociates at elevated temperatures. The paper attributes this temperature increase to hydrogen's unique combustion properties, including its high flame speed and calorific value, which lead to more rapid heat release and sustained high-temperature conditions during combustion. The absence of carbon in hydrogen eliminates soot radiation, reducing in-cylinder heat losses and further contributing to temperature elevation. These combined effects make NOx formation particularly sensitive to hydrogen inclusion rates, especially at higher engine loads where baseline temperatures are already elevated.

original_text.2: Hydrogen-fueled diesel engines emit more NOx because of higher in-cylinder temperatures.
